intro: Haplopappus venetus var. argutus, commonly known as the roughleaf desert parsley, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive leaf morphology. The plant has finely divided, hairy leaves that are typically gray-green in color, adapted to arid environments. Its small yellow flowers bloom in summer, and the plant produces small, bristly seeds that are dispersed by the wind. It is often found in dry, rocky soils and is considered a hardy, drought-tolerant species.
